articles.headline: Hollywood Head Spinner: Universal Spends Big for New ‘Exorcist’ Trilogy
articles.snippet: The deal, expected to be announced this week, is for more than $400 million and is a direct response to the streaming giants that are upending the film industry’s economics.
articles.abstract: The deal, expected to be announced this week, is for more than $400 million and is a direct response to the streaming giants that are upending the film industry’s economics.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Heads are spinning in Hollywood: Universal Pictures and its streaming-service cousin have closed a $400 million-plus megadeal to buy a new “Exorcist” trilogy, signaling a sudden willingness to compete head-on with the technology giants that are upending entertainment industry economics.

articles.headline: Inflation Has Arrived, but Washington Isn’t Racing to Limit Price Pops
articles.snippet: Policymakers, now more attuned to the costs of choking off growth early, are sticking by a patient approach as prices rise.
articles.abstract: Policymakers, now more attuned to the costs of choking off growth early, are sticking by a patient approach as prices rise.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inflation has long been the boogeyman haunting the nightmares of economic policymakers from both parties — and controlling it has been a top economic priority. But as the economy reopens from pandemic shutdowns and prices spike, it is becoming clear just how much that conventional wisdom has shifted in recent years.

articles.headline: Latino Voters Moved Toward Republicans. Now Biden Wants Them Back.
articles.snippet: Did Democrats take the Hispanic vote for granted in 2020? Some in the party think they did, and can’t afford the same mistakes going forward.
articles.abstract: Did Democrats take the Hispanic vote for granted in 2020? Some in the party think they did, and can’t afford the same mistakes going forward.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alejandra Gomez was surprised, but pleased, by a flurry of phone calls from the White House in the spring, offering updates on its efforts toward an immigration overhaul. Officials also asked what her Arizona-based advocacy group thought of its work on voting rights and how the pandemic relief package was affecting the state.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Medina and Lisa Lerer

articles.headline: The Pandemic Changed How We Spent Our Time
articles.snippet: Minute-by-minute data offers a glimpse of how we suddenly adapted to a different way of living in 2020 — and how those changes varied greatly across groups.
articles.abstract: Minute-by-minute data offers a glimpse of how we suddenly adapted to a different way of living in 2020 — and how those changes varied greatly across groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: Minute-by-minute data offers a glimpse of how we suddenly adapted to a different way of living in 2020 — and how those changes varied greatly across groups.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman and Ella Koeze

articles.headline: Groceries in 10 Minutes: Delivery Start-Ups Crowd City Streets Across Globe
articles.snippet: Venture capital’s newest darling is the online rapid grocery delivery industry. Getir, a six-year-old Turkish company, is trying to outpace its new competitors in a worldwide expansion.
articles.abstract: Venture capital’s newest darling is the online rapid grocery delivery industry. Getir, a six-year-old Turkish company, is trying to outpace its new competitors in a worldwide expansion.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Zipping around central London, among the bikes and scooters of Uber Eats, Just Eat and Deliveroo, is a new entrant promising almost instantaneous satisfaction for your craving for a bar of chocolate or pint of ice cream: Getir, a Turkish company that says it will deliver your groceries in 10 minutes.

articles.headline: ‘They Have My Sister’: As Uyghurs Speak Out, China Targets Their Families
articles.snippet: Activists overseas who denounce China’s repression in Xinjiang have found that relatives back home were imprisoned, or worse.
articles.abstract: Activists overseas who denounce China’s repression in Xinjiang have found that relatives back home were imprisoned, or worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: She was a gifted agricultural scientist educated at prestigious universities in Shanghai and Tokyo. She said she wanted to help farmers in poor areas, like her hometown in Xinjiang, in western China. But because of her uncle’s activism for China’s oppressed Muslim Uyghurs, her family and friends said, the Chinese state made her a security target.

articles.headline: BuzzFeed Is Going Public. What Now for Vice and Vox?
articles.snippet: The digital media companies that once seemed to have a lock on the future are making plans to get bigger and pay back their investors.
articles.abstract: The digital media companies that once seemed to have a lock on the future are making plans to get bigger and pay back their investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not so long ago, when newspapers and magazines were going out of business all across the country, BuzzFeed and a few other fast-growing web publications seemed like the future of the news business.
articles.byline: By Edmund Lee and Lauren Hirsch

articles.headline: ‘A hit man sent them.’ Police at the Capitol recount the horrors of Jan. 6 as the inquiry begins.
articles.snippet: The first hearing of the special House committee investigating the attack, which included testimony from four police officers who fought off the mob, has concluded.
articles.abstract: The first hearing of the special House committee investigating the attack, which included testimony from four police officers who fought off the mob, has concluded.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One officer described how rioters attempted to gouge out his eye and called him a traitor as they sought to invade the Capitol.
articles.byline: By Luke Broadwater and Nicholas Fandos
